Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Next-Generation Simultaneously Ion- and Electron-Conducting Block Copolymer Binders for Battery Electrodes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rechargeable lithium ion batteries help to enable sustainable energy systems by storing electricity generated by intermittent renewable resources such as wind and solar energy, or by powering zero-emission electric vehicles charged by electricity from renewable resources. Lithium-ion batteries are comprised of a variety of materials for storing and releasing ions, transporting electrical charge, and maintaining mechanical integrity. Binder materials, although representing less than 10% of the battery by weight, are an important component for maintaining adhesion between the different materials. This collaborative project will develop a new class of binding materials based on polymers that are both conductive and electrochemically active, enhancing both mechanical and electrochemical properties. The scientific research will establish the principles for the design of electroactive polymeric binders for lithium ion batteries. The key innovation is that the polymer material will be designed at the molecular level to enable these electroactive properties. When properly designed at the molecular level, these polymers have potential to improve the stability and performance of a wide range of battery electrodes. The educational activities associated with this project will provide opportunities for community college students to work on the development of conjugated polymers for energy storage. Furthermore, outreach activities to K-12 students from diverse and underrepresented groups are planned through Chemistry Open House, Empowering Leadership Alliance, Schlumberger Energy Institute, and the Sally Ride Festival.

In lithium ion battery systems, polymeric binders provide adhesion with various electrode components and stabilize contact with the current collector. However, current binders are electronically inactive. Substantial improvements in electrode performance and capacity may be possible through the molecular design of electroactive polymeric binders. Towards this end, polymeric binders that are ion-conducting, electron-conducting, and redox-active as well as mechanically stable, are needed. The goal of this research is to develop and understand the functionality of the polymer materials needed to enable these properties. The research plan will consider polymers that contain electronically conductive backbones, side chains for self-doping and ionic conductivity, and redox-active carbonyl groups. The research plan has three objectives. The first objective is to synthesize co-polymers that conduct both ions and electrons simultaneously, and characterize their resulting structural, physiochemical, and electrochemical properties. The second objective is to characterize the electrochemical/mechanical properties of hybrid anodes containing a silicon base material and polymer binders developed under the first objective. The third objective is to incorporate redox-active groups into the polymer backbone and examine their role on conductive polymer binder properties. Through this approach, this work seeks to establish the fundamental properties that influence conductivity, mechanical integrity, and electrochemical activity of the polymeric materials to suggest design rules for electroactive binders that are compatible with a broad range of electrode materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The focus of this proposal is on the fundamental understanding of polymeric binders for battery electrodes. Batteries contain active materials that are bound to together using a polymer binder to form an electrode. Conventional polymer binders serve only one purpose (mechanical binding) and are unable to conduct electrons or ions. Thus, current electrode design is concerned with lowering the required amount of binder to minimize what  some consider to be deadweight. The goal of this project is to develop and to fundamentally understand the behavior of multifunctional electrode binders. These binders not only adhere the active materials together, they are capable of mixed electron and ion conduction. Specifically, this project studied the interplay between different functionalities and possible tradeoffs in the design of such binders that contain intrinsically conductive backbones, side chains for self-doping and ionic conductivity, and redox-active.  The specific research objectives were to: 1) Investigate the interplay between ionic and electronic conductivities in polymer binders; 2) Understand how polymeric binders interact mechanically and electrochemically with electrode materials with severe volume expansion, and 3) Elucidate the impact of redox activity in the polymer binder on long-term electrode performance and stability.

At the conclusion of the project, several notable findings were revealed. The findings were largely centered around silicon anode active materials due to its high theoretical capacity  and notable volumetric expansion challenges. An n-type polyfluorene derivative was examined as a binder for silicon anodes and as an active material on its own. Polyacrylamides and tannic acids were revealed too be very effective binders for silicon anodes due to the favorable hydrogen bonding interactions among the materials. A naphthalene diimide – ethylene glycol co-polymer was revealed to have excellent charge-discharge rates as an active material on its own due to the fast ion transport characteristics. Finally, the self-doped polymers were revealed to positively  impact charge storage in vanadium pentoxide cathodes.

Broader Impacts. Taken together, these research efforts have broadly impacted the fields of batteries and energy storage. This work has provided new knowledge and new chemistries that may  prove practical or translatable to other battery anode and cathode materials. If successful in the long-term, this effort could manifest in batteries that have higher energy and power densities, or smaller footprints. This work also positively impacted graduate and undergraduate student trainees and K-12 students. Two PhD students and three undergraduate students from Texas A&M University were mentored (over half female). One PhD student is pursuing his post-doctoral education and a second will soon enter the U.S. workforce. Outreach was conducted with the general public via Expanding Your Horizons and local elementary schools.
